title: Term Life Insurance Overview
content: Term life insurance provides coverage for a fixed period (for example, 10, 20, or 30 years) and pays a lump-sum death benefit if the insured dies within the term; it generally has lower premiums and no cash value.

title: Whole Life Insurance Basics
content: Whole life insurance offers lifelong coverage and includes a savings-like cash value component that grows over time; premiums are higher but part of the policy builds value you can borrow against.

title: Endowment Plan Explained
content: Endowment plans combine life cover with a savings objective, paying a maturity benefit if the policyholder survives the term or a death benefit if they die during the term.

title: Unit-Linked Insurance Plans
content: Unit-linked insurance plans (ULIPs) split the premium between insurance cover and market-linked investments, so part of the value fluctuates with fund performance and carries investment risk.

title: Group Life Insurance
content: Group life insurance provides coverage for members of a group—often employees—under a single master policy, typically arranged and paid for by an employer or organization.

title: Joint Life Insurance
content: Joint life insurance covers two people on one policy, commonly spouses; the plan may pay on the first death, or in some designs, pay only after both insured persons have died.

title: Child Life Insurance Plans
content: Child plans are designed to build savings for a child’s future needs such as education while often providing life cover for the parent or policyholder depending on plan design.

title: Money-Back Policies
content: Money-back life policies return a portion of the sum assured at periodic intervals during the policy term, providing liquidity while the policy remains in force.

title: Convertible Term Insurance
content: Convertible term insurance lets the policyholder convert a term policy to a permanent policy (such as whole life) without further medical underwriting, subject to conversion rules and deadlines.

title: Return of Premium Term Policy
content: Return-of-premium term policies refund the premiums paid if the insured survives the policy term, usually at a higher premium compared with standard term insurance.

title: Credit Life Insurance
content: Credit life insurance is tied to a loan and pays off the outstanding loan balance if the borrower dies before the loan is repaid, protecting lenders and sometimes borrowers’ families from debt burden.

title: Final Expense Insurance
content: Final expense insurance is a small whole-life policy intended to cover funeral and other end-of-life expenses, with relatively low face amounts and simplified underwriting.

title: Simplified Issue Life Insurance
content: Simplified issue life insurance requires no medical exam and issues coverage based on a brief health questionnaire, enabling faster approval but with limited coverage amounts.

title: Guaranteed Issue Life Insurance
content: Guaranteed issue life insurance provides coverage without health questions or exams; acceptance is guaranteed but premiums are higher and coverage amounts are typically lower.

title: Survivorship (Second-to-Die) Policies
content: Survivorship life insurance covers two lives and pays the death benefit only after both insured individuals have died; often used for estate planning.

title: Indexed Universal Life (IUL)
content: Indexed universal life insurance credits interest to the cash value based on a stock market index’s performance while offering a death benefit and flexible premiums.

title: Variable Universal Life
content: Variable universal life policies allow the policyholder to allocate cash value among investment sub-accounts, exposing the cash value to market risk and potential growth.

title: Annuity-Like Life Plans
content: Some life contracts can include annuity-style settlement options that pay beneficiaries regular income over time instead of a single lump-sum payment.

title: Family Income Benefit
content: Family income benefit policies pay a regular income to beneficiaries for a defined period after the insured’s death, providing ongoing support instead of a lump sum.

title: Mortgage Protection Insurance
content: Mortgage protection insurance is a term-type product designed to clear the mortgage balance if the borrower dies during the mortgage term.

title: Decreasing Term Insurance
content: Decreasing term insurance provides a declining death benefit over time, often used to match the reducing balance of a mortgage or loan.

title: Level Term Insurance
content: Level term insurance keeps the death benefit constant throughout the policy term, providing predictable coverage for dependents.

title: Single-Premium Whole Life
content: Single-premium whole life is paid with a one-time lump-sum premium, immediately generating cash value and life cover without future premium payments.

title: Limited-Payment Whole Life
content: Limited-payment whole life requires premiums only for a limited number of years (for example, 10 or 20), after which the policy remains in force for life.

title: Permanent Life Insurance Overview
content: Permanent life insurance refers to policies that provide lifetime coverage and usually include a cash value component that accumulates over time.

title: Indexed Life Policy Features
content: Indexed life policies credit interest to cash value based on index performance with caps and floors; they combine downside protection with index-linked upside.

title: Participating (With-Profits) Policies
content: Participating or with-profits policies may declare bonuses based on insurer performance, increasing the benefits for policyholders in addition to guaranteed amounts.

title: Non-Participating Policies
content: Non-participating policies do not share insurer profits and typically offer guaranteed benefits without bonus declarations.

title: Low-Value Funeral Cover
content: Low-value funeral cover provides a small fixed benefit meant to cover funeral expenses and often has simplified underwriting and quick issue.

title: Accidental Death Benefit as Standalone
content: Stand-alone accidental death policies pay an additional benefit if death results directly from an accident; they do not usually cover illness-related deaths.

title: Accelerated Death Benefit Feature
content: Some life policies include an accelerated death benefit that allows early payment of part of the death benefit if the insured is diagnosed with a terminal illness.

title: Return of Mortality Premium Option
content: Certain term products offer a return of mortality premium where part of the premium is returned if the insured survives the term, often at higher cost.

title: Indexed-Linked Savings Plan
content: Indexed-linked savings plans tie a portion of returns to market indices while offering life cover, blending savings and protection features.

title: Graduated Benefit Policies
content: Graduated benefit plans increase the sum assured or benefits over time to keep pace with inflation or growing family needs.

title: Income Replacement Policies
content: Income replacement policies are designed specifically to replace lost income for beneficiaries, often structured as regular payments rather than a lump sum.

title: Key Person Life Insurance
content: Key person life insurance protects a business against the financial loss resulting from the death of an essential employee by paying a benefit to the company.

title: Buy-Sell Agreement Life Policies
content: Buy-sell life policies fund business succession agreements by providing liquidity to buy a deceased partner’s share in a business.

title: Short-Term Temporary Cover
content: Short-term temporary life cover offers brief protection for a specific need (for example, travel or a short loan) and is designed to be low-cost and quick to issue.

title: Level Premium vs. Stepped Premium
content: Level premium policies charge the same premium every year, while stepped premium policies increase premiums as the insured ages.

title: Flexible Premium Policies
content: Flexible premium policies allow policyholders to vary the amount and timing of premium payments within policy-specified limits, offering more cash-flow flexibility.
